questions.text:
A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive pain in his right hip and lower back over the past 4 weeks. He describes the pain as dull and constant. It is worse with exertion and at night. Over the past 2 months, he has helped his son with renovating his home, which required heavy lifting and kneeling. His father died of prostate cancer. He drinks 2–3 beers daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows localized tenderness over the right hip and groin area; range of motion is decreased. Hearing is mildly decreased on the right side. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
15 g/dL


Serum



 Total protein
6.5 g/dL


 Total bilirubin
0.8 mg/dL


 Alanine aminotransferase
20 U/L


 Alkaline phosphatase (ALP)
950 U/L


 γ-Glutamyltransferase (GGT)
40 U/L (N=5–50)


 Calcium
9 mg/dL


 Phosphate
4 mg/dL


 Parathyroid hormone
45 pg/mL


An x-ray of the hip shows cortical thickening and prominent trabecular markings. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Proliferation of plasma cells in the bone marrow
Decreased bone mass with microarchitectural disruption
Infarction of the bone and marrow

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abnormal proliferation of plasma cells in the bone marrow is seen in patients with multiple myeloma (MM), which commonly manifests with bone pain and radiographic findings of osteolytic lesions, osteopenia, and/or pathological fractures. Classic laboratory findings include hyperproteinemia, anemia, elevated creatinine, and hypercalcemia. While this patient does have bone pain, none of the other features of MM are present and his x-ray findings are not consistent with this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Defective bone matrix mineralization is seen in patients with osteomalacia, a bone disorder that is most commonly due to vitamin D deficiency but may also arise secondary to proximal tubular acidosis, hypophosphatemia, or low oral calcium intake. The presentation and associated laboratory findings of patients with osteomalacia depend largely on the underlying etiology, but generally, osteomalacia manifests with diffuse bone pain, muscle weakness, and/or pathological fractures. Imaging is nonspecific and often reveals low bone mineral density and cortical thinning. This patient's x-ray findings and isolated elevation of ALP are not consistent with this diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

An increased rate of bone remodeling is characteristic of Paget disease of bone (PDB), a chronic, benign condition that is likely hereditary. Most patients are asymptomatic, and bone pain is a late manifestation of the disease. As in this patient, hearing impairment can occur and is thought to be related to cochlear damage. This patient's isolated elevation of ALP is consistent with PDB. While osteolytic bone lesions may be seen earlier in the course of the disease, late disease is dominated by sclerotic bone with cortical thickening, and microfissures and fractures are also common. PDB can usually be diagnosed with laboratory studies and imaging alone. Bisphosphonates are the mainstay of treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased bone mass and microarchitectural disruption are characteristic of osteoporosis, which is classically either diagnosed on routine screening or after a pathological fracture has occurred due to minimal trauma. Osteoporosis is most frequently seen in postmenopausal women and commonly affected sites include the lumbar spine, femoral head, distal radius, and humerus. While this patient's age and alcohol put him at increased risk for osteoporosis, laboratory findings in osteoporosis are usually within normal range, unlike this patient's isolated elevation of ALP.

E) INCORRECT:

Osteonecrosis (avascular necrosis) is characterized by infarction of the bone and marrow. It most commonly affects the head of the femur, scaphoid bone, and/or shoulder. Risk factors include chronic steroid use, excessive alcohol use, and sickle cell disease. While this patient does have a history of alcohol use, his elevated ALP and pelvic x-ray findings are more suggestive of another diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Bone is a common site of metastatic prostate cancer, which is characterized by malignant tumor infiltration and subsequent osteoblastic destruction. This patient's dull pain in the lower back and hip could be a sign of bone metastatic prostate cancer and he is at increased risk of developing the disease due to his positive family history. While this patient's radiographic findings could be consistent with an osteoblastic process, he lacks other typical symptoms of prostate cancer (e.g., weight loss, urinary complaints). Moreover, metastatic prostate cancer frequently results in disordered calcium and phosphate metabolism. This patient's hearing loss in combination with an isolated elevation of ALP suggests a different diagnosis.
questions.hint: Mild hearing loss, bone pain, and isolated elevation of ALP suggest a specific disorder of the osteoclasts.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old postmenopausal woman comes to the physician with a 6-month history of difficulty biting and chewing that is becoming progressively worse. She has been taking acetaminophen for headaches and nonspecific pain in her hips and back. She also says that her hearing has been deteriorating as she gets older. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a mildly tender, 1-cm, bony, immobile swelling on the left side of her forehead. Intraoral examination shows bilateral expansion of the maxillary alveolus and malocclusion. Audiometry shows bilateral mixed conductive and sensorineural hearing loss. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14.6 g/dL


Leukocyte count
9000/mm3



Platelet count
256,000/mm3



Serum



 Alkaline phosphatase

1100 U/L


 Vitamin D
40 ng/ml (N = 20–100)


 Calcium
9.5 mg/dL


 Parathyroid hormone
40 pg/mL


A plain x-ray of the skull is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Parathyroidectomy is the definitive treatment for primary hyperparathyroidism. Osteitis fibrosa cystica (brown tumor) can occur in patients with severe disease and may manifest with dental malocclusion. Hyperparathyroidism also causes elevated ALP and nonspecific bone pain. However, headaches and hearing loss are not commonly seen in hyperparathyroidism. Serum parathyroid hormone and calcium levels would also be elevated in primary hyperparathyroidism, making it an unlikely cause of her symptoms and elevated ALP.
Image Description:

X-ray head (lateral view)

Numerous small well-defined lucent calvarial lesions correlate with trabecular bone resorption (examples indicated by green overlay). The salt and pepper (or pepper-pot) appearance is a feature of primary hyperparathyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

Hematopoietic cell transplantation after induction chemotherapy is the recommended treatment for symptomatic multiple myeloma (MM). Skeletal manifestations of MM include osteopenia and osteolytic lesions, but not skeletal expansion, as seen in this patient with enlarged maxillary processes causing dental malocclusion. Moreover, elevated ALP is uncommon in patients with MM, and if present should raise suspicion of a pathological fracture. Finally, anemia and hypercalcemia are commonly seen in MM but are absent in this patient.
Image Description:

X-ray skull (lateral view) of a patient with a history of multiple myeloma

Multiple punched-out lytic lesions (examples indicated by green overlay) are visible. This appearance is termed “raindrop sign” from the resemblance of these lesions to raindrops splashing upon hitting a surface.

An expanded differential of lucent skull lesions includes osteoporosis of aging, hyperparathyroidism, metastatic disease, anemias (e.g., sickle cell and thalassemia), and the lytic phase of Paget disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Radiation therapy is a treatment option for skeletal metastases. Although skeletal metastases can manifest with deformities of the skull and elevated ALP, x-ray of the skull would show well-defined sclerotic/lytic lesions and not the diffuse cortical thickening seen here. Patients with skeletal metastases also typically have hypercalcemia, whereas bilateral hearing loss is not commonly associated with bone metastases.

D) INCORRECT:

Transsphenoidal hypophysectomy is the surgical treatment of choice for a resectable pituitary adenoma secreting growth hormone, which results in acromegaly. Patients with acromegaly may present with enlargement of facial bones (resulting in malocclusion of the teeth), headaches (due to an intracranial mass), nonspecific bone pain, and elevated serum ALP (due to increased bone growth). However, there would be a diffuse enlargement of the bones in acromegaly (e.g., of the hands, feet, mandible) rather than localized bony growths. In addition, a cranial x-ray of a patient with acromegaly would show frontal bossing and enlargement of the bones but not sclerotic and lytic lesions.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgery and adjuvant chemotherapy is the treatment of choice for osteosarcoma of the skull, which can manifest with dental malocclusion and elevated ALP. Although osteosarcoma can occur spontaneously or as a complication of Paget's disease, the cranial x-ray in osteosarcoma would show a localized lesion with mixed radiodense and radiolucent areas, loss of trabecular pattern, Codman triangle, and destruction of the cortex of the affected bone (the maxilla, in this case). This patient has no features of osteosarcoma on the cranial x-ray and bilateral maxillary swellings.

F) CORRECT:

Bisphosphonates are the mainstay of treatment for symptomatic Paget disease of bone because they inhibit osteoclastic activity, limiting bone resorption and disease progression. IV zoledronate is the preferred bisphosphonate in patients with no contraindications (e.g., renal insufficiency) because it is very effective, can be administered as a single IV dose, and has a more sustained response compared to oral bisphosphonates. If necessary, treatment is repeated five years after the initial dose. In addition, vitamin D3 and calcium supplementation are recommended for patients on bisphosphonate therapy. If bisphosphonates are poorly tolerated, calcitonin may be used. NSAIDs and acetaminophen can be used to treat pain.

Following the administration of zoledronate, most patients develop a self-limited flu-like illness, including fever and myalgia, as a result of an acute phase response. Bisphosphonates can also cause esophagitis, incapacitating myalgia and arthralgia, and osteonecrosis of the jaw.

G) INCORRECT:

Estrogen replacement therapy is a treatment option for postmenopausal patients with osteoporosis resistant to first-line therapy with bisphosphonates. Estrogen physiologically prevents bone breakdown by stimulating osteoblasts and inhibiting osteoclasts. Primary osteoporosis is seen in postmenopausal women due to the decrease in estrogen levels. Osteoporosis is typically asymptomatic, and although patients with osteoporosis have an elevated ALP and normal serum calcium, x-rays would show increased radiolucency of the bones rather than the cortical thickening or sclerosis seen here.
questions.hint: Diffuse cortical thickening and multiple sclerotic lesions seen on skull x-ray, headache, bone pain, grossly elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP), and mixed hearing loss with normal levels of serum calcium, parathyroid hormone, and vitamin D are characteristic of Paget disease of bone.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of headaches and back pain for 5 months. He also noted that his favorite hat no longer fits him. He has hypertension, hypothyroidism, and benign prostate hyperplasia. His father had prostate cancer and osteoporosis. Current medications include calcium supplementation, metoprolol, and L-thyroxine. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, there is enlargement of the anterior head. An x-ray of the skull shows a thickened calvaria and osteoblastic and osteolytic lesions. Serum studies are most likely to show which of the following sets of findings in this patient?



Calcium
Phosphate
Alkaline phosphatase
Parathyroid hormone



A
Increased
normal
increased
normal


B
Increased
decreased
increased
increased


C
Normal
normal
increased
normal


D
Normal
normal
normal
normal


E
Decreased
increased
normal
decreased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated Ca2+ and serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels with normal phosphate and parathyroid hormone (PTH) are most consistent with secondary malignant bone tumors. The formation of osteolytic lesions results in the release of Ca2+ and phosphate. Elevated serum ALP reflects the compensatory activation of osteoblasts. Phosphate is excreted renally and PTH is unaffected or may be decreased due to hypercalcemia. While secondary malignancy can manifest with back pain, it does not explain this patient's headache and skull enlargement. Mixed osteolytic-osteoblastic lesions, as seen in this patient's x-ray, are consistent with secondary malignancies; however, these changes are only visible on x-ray if extensive density loss occurs, while periosteal reactions (e.g., cortical thickening) tend to be scarce if at all present.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated Ca2+, parathyroid hormone (PTH), and serum alkaline phosphatase with reduced phosphate are consistent with primary hyperparathyroidism. Elevated PTH levels lead to the release of calcium phosphate from bones as well as increased renal elimination of phosphate. Primary hyperparathyroidism usually manifests with signs of hypercalcemia, including diffuse muscle and bone pain, fatigue, lack of appetite, nausea, constipation, and polyuria and polydipsia. X-ray of the skull would show granular decalcification (salt-and-pepper skull). Thickening of the calvaria and concurrent osteoblastic lesions would not be expected.

C) CORRECT:

Elevated serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and normal Ca2+, phosphate, and parathyroid hormone (PTH) are most consistent with PDB. Serum ALP, which is a marker of bone formation (osteoblastic activity), is elevated in PDB because the rate of bone turnover is increased. Since both bone formation and bone resorption occur at increased rates, the overall equilibrium is not disturbed and Ca2+, phosphate, and PTH levels are normal. Increased bone turnover causes normal lamellar bone to be replaced by weak woven bone, which is often enlarged, can easily be deformed, and is highly susceptible to fractures. Medical therapy with bisphosphonates should be initiated in all patients with active disease (raised ALP levels or active disease foci on skeletal scintigraphy).

D) INCORRECT:

Normal serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP), Ca2+, phosphate, and parathyroid hormone is most consistent with primary osteoporosis. The underlying mechanism is not fully understood but the decrease in both osteoclast and osteoblast activity, in which osteoblasts produce osteoid slower than osteoclasts resorb bone, subsequently results in weaker, less densely mineralized bone. Serum biochemistry and hormone levels are typically normal but serum ALP may be elevated following a pathological fracture. Although osteoporosis could be responsible for this patient's back pain, it does not explain this patient's headache, skull enlargement, and radiographic signs. Instead, x-ray would show increased radiolucency in cortical bones.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased Ca2+ and parathyroid hormone (PTH), elevated phosphate, and normal serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels are most consistent with hypoparathyroidism. In the absence of PTH, Ca2+ levels drop due to insufficient gastrointestinal absorption and renal and bone resorption. Renal phosphate excretion is also reduced, resulting in elevated phosphate levels. Serum ALP, which is a marker for bone formation (osteoblast activity), is normal. Hypocalcemia can trigger a variety of symptoms, ranging from muscle cramps to seizures and heart failure. Manifestations of chronic hypoparathyroidism include movement disorders (due to basal ganglia calcifications), cataracts, and skeletal or dental abnormalities. X-ray would show increased bone mineral density (osteosclerosis) and no osteolytic lesions. Skull enlargement would not be expected.
questions.hint: Headaches and back pain in conjunction with thickened calvarium and concurrent osteoblastic and osteolytic lesions suggest Paget disease of bone (PDB), which manifests with cranial enlargement in ∼ 40% of cases.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing pain in his right leg for 2 months. The pain persists throughout the day and does not improve with rest. He tried taking acetaminophen, but it provided no relief from his symptoms. There is no family history of serious illness. He does not smoke. He occasionally drinks one beer. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, the right tibia is bowing anteriorly; range of motion is limited by pain. An x-ray of the right leg shows a deformed tibia with multiple lesions of increased and decreased density and a thickened cortical bone. Laboratory studies show markedly elevated serum alkaline phosphatase and normal calcium and phosphate levels. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bone sequestrum is a complication of chronic osteomyelitis, which can manifest with persistent, localized bone pain. However, chronic osteomyelitis generally develops slowly (over months or years), inflammatory markers would be elevated, and x-ray would show bone destruction, sequestrum formation, and periosteal reactions.
Image Description:

X-ray leg (left; AP view) of a child

A fragment of bone (green overlay) has separated from adjacent bone and is surrounded by a lucent rim (red outline).

A bony sequestrum is devascularized bone that may be seen in the setting of chronic osteomyelitis. A sequestrum may act as a nidus for ongoing infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Renal insufficiency is a complication of multiple myeloma (MM), which can also cause localized bone pain. However, monoclonal plasma cell proliferation in the bone marrow in MM results in hypercalcemia, anemia, and exclusively lytic bone lesions, which is inconsistent with this patient's presentation.

C) INCORRECT:

High-output cardiac failure is a rare complication of PDB. It arises as a result of increased vascularity within pagetic bones and the formation of arteriovenous fistulas within the bone, which, in turn, result in an increase in cardiac output to meet increased peripheral demand. High-output cardiac failure is usually associated with high PDB disease activity, as evidenced by an ALP level that is ≥ 4 times greater than normal and extensive skeletal involvement. Another complication of PDB is more common.

D) INCORRECT:

PDB is associated with a high rate of bone remodeling, and there is a risk of malignant degeneration into osteosarcoma. However, this is very rare, occurring in < 1% of cases. Another complication is more common.

E) CORRECT:

Approx. 40% of patients with PDB have skull involvement, which can result in hearing impairment. Ankylosis of the ossicles can lead to conductive hearing loss while narrowing of the internal auditory meatus can lead to compression of the vestibulocochlear nerve and subsequent sensorineural hearing loss. Medical therapy with bisphosphonates should be initiated in all patients with active disease (raised ALP levels or active disease foci on skeletal scintigraphy).

Bone pain of PDB is often resistant to NSAIDs and acetaminophen, which is consistent with this patient's presentation. However, NSAIDs can be used to treat flu-like symptoms that arise during treatment with bisphosphonates.

F) INCORRECT:

Pancytopenia can occur secondary to numerous conditions that involve the bone marrow space and hematopoiesis. For instance, it may be seen in osteopetrosis, a diffuse bone disease that results in progressive sclerosis of the bone. However, x-ray would show homogenous, marbled thickening of cortical and trabecular bone, and serum calcium levels would be decreased.
questions.hint: In a patient with bone pain, a deformed tibia (saber shin) with thickened cortical bone and both sclerotic and osteolytic lesions seen on x-ray, in combination with an isolated elevation of serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP), are suggestive of Paget disease of bone (PDB). This condition most commonly affects individuals > 50 years of age.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician because of lower back pain that began suddenly 2 weeks ago after getting up from her chair. She has hypertension, chronic bilateral knee pain, and a history of breast cancer 15 years ago that was treated with lumpectomy. Her mother has rheumatoid arthritis. Medications include hydrochlorothiazide and acetaminophen. She appears well. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation of the lower spine. Both knees are enlarged and swollen. Neurologic examination shows bilateral sensorineural hearing impairment. Her gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) is 30 U/L (N: 0–30 U/L), alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is 310 U/L, and serum calcium is 10.2 mg/dL. A spinal x-ray shows a fracture in the L4 vertebra. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Type 1 osteopetrosis is characterized by increased bone mineralization and can manifest with bone pain, pathological fracture, and increased ALP levels. However, this condition manifests during early childhood and is also associated with short stature and intellectual disability. Mortality is high and most children die before age five.

B) INCORRECT:

Osteoporosis is characterized by a decrease in bone mineral density and is most common in postmenopausal women. While osteoporosis can lead to pathological fractures, the diagnosis would not be consistent with this patient's hearing loss and chronic knee pain. In addition, while mild ALP elevation could be seen in osteoporosis, the degree of elevation in this patient would be unusual.

C) INCORRECT:

Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) is characterized by cholestatic liver disease and may present with elevated ALP levels. However, in the absence of elevated GGT and other typical clinical findings of PBC (e.g., fatigue, pruritus, right upper quadrant pain, hyperpigmentation, hepatomegaly), a different diagnosis is more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Osteomalacia is characterized by impaired mineralization of the bone and can also manifest with chronic bone pain, pathological fractures, and increased ALP levels. X-ray findings typically include low bone mineral density, thin cortices, and pseudofractures. Osteomalacia is associated with hypocalcemia and would not explain this patient's hearing loss, making a different diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

The diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) should always be considered in patients presenting with polyarthritis and concerning family history. However, this patient lacks other typical findings of RA (such as involvement of the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints), and RA is not associated with pathological fractures or elevated ALP levels.
Image Description:

Symmetrical swelling of the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and wrist joints.

F) INCORRECT:

McCune-Albright syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by precocious puberty, café-au-lait spots, and fibrous dysplasia of the bone. While it can cause pathological fractures, this condition is very rare and manifests during childhood.

G) CORRECT:

Paget disease of bone is an idiopathic disease associated with increased bone remodeling, which is caused by increased activity of osteoblasts and osteoclasts. This leads to the formation of disorganized (woven) bone that is weaker than normal bone and abnormal in structure. Paget disease of bone therefore manifests with pathological fractures, bone pain with overlying erythema (due to increased vascularity of the underlying bone), and hearing loss (due to ankylosis of the ossicles or compression of the vestibulocochlear nerve). Elevated serum ALP concentrations with normal serum calcium and phosphate concentrations, as seen in this patient, are a hallmark laboratory finding. Treatment consists of bisphosphonates.

H) INCORRECT:

This patient's history of breast cancer puts her at increased risk of malignant bone metastases, which can also manifest with bone pain, pathological fracture, and increased ALP levels. However, the normal serum calcium levels and absence of systemic symptoms make metastases unlikely. In addition, hearing loss and chronic knee pain suggest a different diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a pathological fracture of the spine, chronic knee pain, impaired hearing, and laboratory markers suggestive of increased bone turnover.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a constant, dull headache and generalized body pains for the past 8 months. She has also had difficulty hearing, which started a month after the onset of the headaches. Five months ago, she had surgery to treat a fracture of the right femur that occurred without a fall or any significant trauma. Five years ago, she underwent total thyroidectomy for localized thyroid carcinoma. She takes levothyroxine and calcium supplements, which she started after menopause. Physical examination reveals a prominent forehead and irregular, tender skull surface. Bony tenderness is present over bilateral hip and knee joints, with decreased range of motion of the right hip joint and increased anterior curvature of both tibias. Laboratory studies show a highly elevated level of alkaline phosphatase, with vitamin D, calcium, and parathyroid hormone levels within normal limits. A plain x-ray of the head is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Lytic lesions with no sclerotic margin
Multiple, well-defined, punched out lytic lesions
Periosteal trabeculations with radiolucent marrow hyperplasia
Lobulated lesions with a thin cortex and ground-glass appearance

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lytic lesions with no sclerotic margin would indicate metastasis to bone. Although this patient has a history of thyroid carcinoma, the localized tumor was excised via total thyroidectomy 5 years ago and she never had any signs of systemic cancer spread such as lymphadenopathy or cancer cachexia. Additionally, bone metastasis would cause elevated serum calcium, which is not the case in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Multiple, well-defined, punched-out lytic lesions are a characteristic finding in multiple myeloma (MM). MM manifests at 50–70 years of age with bone pain and can lead to pathological fractures. However, MM would cause massively increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate, hypercalcemia, elevated creatinine, and elevated total protein.
Image Description:

X-ray skull (lateral view) of a patient with a history of multiple myeloma

Multiple punched-out lytic lesions (examples indicated by green overlay) are visible. This appearance is termed “raindrop sign” from the resemblance of these lesions to raindrops splashing upon hitting a surface.

An expanded differential of lucent skull lesions includes osteoporosis of aging, hyperparathyroidism, metastatic disease, anemias (e.g., sickle cell and thalassemia), and the lytic phase of Paget disease.

C) CORRECT:

Mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions are typical radiological findings in PDB. On x-ray, the osteolytic lesions appear as foci of decreased density (usually as a result of decreased mineralization), and the sclerotic lesions can be identified by their increased density (increased mineralization). Another important x-ray finding is thickened cortical bone. The laboratory findings in this patient are also characteristic of PDB, as increased serum alkaline phosphatase is often the only abnormal marker of bone metabolism, whereas calcium, phosphate, and parathyroid hormone are usually normal.
Image Description:

X-ray skull (lateral view)

The calvarium is markedly thickened (left right arrow), with widening of the diploic space. Numerous ill-defined lytic (examples indicated by green overlay) and sclerotic (examples indicated by red overlay) lesions are present.

The presence of multiple poorly marginated sclerotic lesions in Paget disease has been termed “cotton wool appearance.”

D) INCORRECT:

Periosteal trabeculations with radiolucent marrow hyperplasia appear in hemolytic anemias (e.g., thalassemia, sickle cell anemia). This patient does not show any laboratory signs of hemolytic anemia, such as elevated lactate dehydrogenase, bilirubin, and reticulocytes, or decreased haptoglobin.
Image Description:

X-ray skull (lateral view) of a child with beta thalassemia

Expansion of the diploic space with thickening of the trabeculae (example indicated by green overlay) is the result of extramedullary hematopoiesis. The hair-on-end appearance (examples indicated by red lines) produced can also be seen in other chronic hemolytic anemias.

E) INCORRECT:

Lobulated lesions with a thin cortex and ground-glass appearance are typical in fibrous dysplasia. Fibrous dysplasia can manifest with bone pain, entrapment neuropathies, pathological fractures, and isolated elevation of ALP. However, the age of onset for fibrous dysplasia ranges from infancy to early adulthood. It is very unlikely that the disease would remain undiagnosed for such a long time.
Image Description:

X-ray skull (a: PA view; b: lateral view)

Bony sclerosis and expansion involve much of the right hemicranium and facial bones (examples indicated by green overlay).

The lesions in this patient were further characterized by CT, confirming the diagnosis of fibrous dysplasia.

Diameter line: bone expansion

F) INCORRECT:

Generalized dense, sclerotic bone is a typical finding in osteopetrosis, which can manifest with pathological fractures and cranial nerve impairment due to cranial hyperostosis. Cranial nerve impairment could cause hearing loss. However, osteopetrosis would cause hypocalcemia and pancytopenia, whereas calcium is normal in this patient and there is no evidence of pancytopenia. Additionally, osteopetrosis is present from birth and the age of onset ranges from infancy to early adulthood.
Image Description:

Anteroposterior x-ray of the hand of an 8-year-old girl: pronounced metaphyseal densities in line with increased sclerotization of the bones of the fingers.
questions.hint: Bone pain and deformity (saber shin), apparent skull enlargement, hearing loss, and a history of a pathological fracture indicate a defect in bone remodeling. Laboratory findings show elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels with other bone-related parameters within normal ranges, suggesting a diagnosis of Paget disease of bone (PDB).

questions.text: A 69-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of severe right hip pain. The pain is worse at night. He has chronic headaches and back pain for which he takes vitamin D, calcium supplements, and ibuprofen. Examination shows hip tenderness and mild sensorineural hearing loss. X-ray of the hip shows a radiolucent lesion in the ilium with a moth-eaten appearance, wide transition zone, and an aggressive periosteal reaction. Wide excision of the lesion is performed. A photomicrograph of a section of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Multiple myeloma commonly affects the axial skeleton (including the pelvis), has a peak incidence at 50–70 years, and would cause radiolucent lesions on x-ray. This patient's history of chronic back pain, chronic headaches (skull involvement), and hearing loss (SNHL) are also consistent with the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. However, multiple myeloma would appear as well-defined (narrow transition zone) lesions on x-ray with a punched-out appearance and minimal periosteal reaction. Furthermore, biopsy of a multiple myeloma lesion would show numerous plasma cells, which are not seen here.
Image Description:

Bone marrow aspirate smear (May-Gruenwald stain; high magnification)

An increased density of plasma cells is visible. Plasma cells possess a round eccentric nucleus (example indicated by yellow hatched overlay) with clock-face chromatin (example indicated by white circle) and a perinuclear halo (perinuclear hof; example indicated by white overlay). Other cell types present include neutrophils (example indicated by blue overlay), lymphocytes (examples indicated by black arrowheads), and erythrocytes (example indicated by blue hatched overlay).
Additionally, the plasma cells in this specimen show features of atypia, e.g., multinucleated cells (example indicated by yellow outline), prominent nucleoli (example indicated by yellow arrowhead), and enlarged as well as irregularly shaped cytoplasm (example indicated by yellow overlay).

The diagnosis of multiple myeloma requires the lesion to consist of monoclonal plasma cells, which is confirmed by kappa or lambda light chain restriction.

B) INCORRECT:

Chondrosarcoma is associated with PDB, often affects the pelvis, can appear as an ill-defined (wide transition zone), radiolucent lesion with a moth-eaten appearance and aggressive periosteal reaction, and show eosinophilic cartilaginous matrix on biopsy, as seen here. However, the biopsy of a chondrosarcoma would also show nests of small, round, anaplastic cartilage cells with a pathognomonic chicken wire mesh appearance, and an x-ray would typically reveal ring-and-arc or popcorn-like calcification within the tumor. These features are not seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

Blue overlays: examples of calcifications; yellow outlines: examples of lobulations; arrowheads: examples of enlarged nuclei

C) CORRECT:

Osteosarcoma is the most common bone malignancy associated with PDB. Osteosarcomas have immature osteoid, which appears as eosinophilic, glassy material around pleomorphic tumor cells. Destruction of normal bone results in an osteolytic (radiolucent) lesion with an ill-defined border (wide transition zone) and a moth-eaten appearance. Aggressive periosteal reactions (e.g., sunburst appearance, Codman triangle) indicate lifting of the periosteum following rapid tumor growth. Other risk factors for developing osteosarcomas are bone infarcts, radiation, retinoblastoma gene mutations, and Li-Fraumeni syndrome.

Secondary osteosarcomas, which develop in diseased bone, typically manifest in older individuals. In contrast, primary osteosarcomas, which develop in previously normal bone, have a peak incidence at 10–20 years of age, with metaphyses of long bones (typically the distal femur, proximal tibia) more commonly affected than flat bones (e.g., the ilium).

D) INCORRECT:

Ewing sarcoma can occur in flat bones such as the ilium and appear as an ill-defined (wide transition zone), radiolucent lesion with a moth-eaten appearance and an aggressive periosteal reaction (e.g., a lamellated “onion-skin” reaction). However, a biopsy would have shown nests of anaplastic small blue cells (primitive neuroectodermal cells) arranged around capillaries (pseudorosettes). Moreover, Ewing sarcoma is not a complication of PDB, which this patient has.
Image Description:

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

E) INCORRECT:

A giant cell tumor of the bone (osteoclastoma), which is a rare complication of PDB, can present as a radiolucent lesion and show multinucleated cells on biopsy, as seen here. However, the multinucleated cells would be larger (giant cells) and contain many more nuclei (typically > 50), and other pathognomic features such as a highly vascular stroma as well as sheets of mononuclear cells would be present. Moreover, osteoclastomas typically affect the epiphyseal regions of long bones, rather than flat bones like the ilium, and an x-ray would show a well-defined (narrow transition zone) lesion with a non-aggressive periosteal reaction and a soap-bubble appearance.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a section from a bone tumor biopsy (H&E stain)

Numerous giant cells containing multiple nuclei are visible throughout the image (examples indicated by yellow overlay). These cells are surrounded by a hypercellular stroma composed of mononuclear cells (examples indicated by black arrowheads).

These features are typical of giant-cell tumors of the bone.
questions.hint: This patient likely has Paget disease of the bone (PDB), which, when symptomatic, manifests with nonspecific features such as bone pain. The sensorineural hearing loss is likely due to bony compression of the vestibulocochlear nerve. Chronically increased bone turnover in patients with long-standing PDB increases the risk of a certain bone malignancy.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents to his physician's office for evaluation of a 9-month history of pain in the midline of his lower back. Treatment with over-the-counter analgesics has not been effective. Physical examination shows point tenderness over the lumbar vertebrae. X-ray of the lumbosacral spine shows coarse trabecular bone with cortical thickening of the L3 vertebra consistent with a “picture-frame appearance.” The L3 vertebra appears slightly larger than L4 on lateral view. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following sets of laboratory findings?



Calcium
Phosphate
Alkaline phosphatase (ALP)
Parathyroid hormone (PTH)



A
Increased
decreased
increased
increased


B
Normal
normal
normal
normal


C
Normal
normal
increased
normal


D
Decreased
decreased
increased
increased


E
Decreased
increased
increased
increased


F
Increased
increased
normal
decreased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated PTH, calcium, and ALP, along with decreased phosphate is consistent with primary hyperparathyroidism. PTH increases serum calcium by stimulating bone turnover and renal excretion of phosphate. X-ray findings in primary hyperparathyroidism include rugger-jersey spine and the tumor-like appearance of osteitis fibrosa cystica. This patient's x-ray findings are inconsistent with primary hyperparathyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

Normal calcium, phosphate, ALP, and PTH is most consistent with osteoporosis and/or osteopetrosis. In osteoporosis, there is a decrease in both osteoblastic and osteoclastic activity; however, osteoclastic activity predominates, which causes the bone to demineralize. This patient's x-ray findings are inconsistent with both osteoporosis and osteopetrosis.
Image Description:

MRI lumbar spine (left: STIR image; right: T1-weighted; sagittal plane)

Compression deformities of the T8, T10, and L4 vertebrae (green overlays) are visible. The T8 and T10 fractures are hyperintense on the STIR image, indicating that they are recent. The compressed superior endplate of L4 is iso- to hypointense, indicating an old or chronic deformity. The hypointense appearance of the L2–3 intervertebral disc (green circle) on the STIR image indicates disc degeneration.

C) CORRECT:

PDB is characterized by an accelerated rate of bone remodeling, which can cause bone pain and pathologic fractures. Increased bone remodeling leads to coarse trabecular bone and sclerosis of the vertebral margins (i.e., “picture-frame” appearance) and can be seen on x-ray, as in this patient. Laboratory findings in PDB show isolated elevation of ALP levels, along with normal calcium, phosphate, and PTH. Calcium and phosphate are not affected because of the balance of increased osteoblastic and osteoclastic activity.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased calcium and phosphate, along with increased ALP and PTH is consistent with secondary hyperparathyroidism due to vitamin D deficiency. Phosphate is decreased due to deficient intestinal absorption from the vitamin D deficiency and increased renal excretion from high PTH levels. X-ray findings in secondary hyperparathyroidism include rugger-jersey spine and the tumor-like appearance of osteitis fibrosa cystica. This patient's x-ray findings are inconsistent with secondary hyperparathyroidism.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased calcium, along with increased phosphate, ALP, and PTH is consistent with secondary hyperparathyroidism due to chronic kidney disease. X-ray findings in secondary hyperparathyroidism include rugger-jersey spine and the tumor-like appearance of osteitis fibrosa cystica. This patient's x-ray findings are inconsistent with secondary hyperparathyroidism.

F) INCORRECT:

Elevated calcium and phosphate, normal ALP, and decreased PTH occurs with hypervitaminosis D or granulomatous diseases, such as sarcoidosis. Clinical features of hypervitaminosis D are mainly caused by hypercalcemia and include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, polyuria, and polydipsia. In granulomatous diseases, calcium is elevated due to increased expression of 1α-hydroxylase in macrophages, which activates vitamin D. This patient lacks evidence of systemic disease.
questions.hint: This patient's x-ray shows coarse trabecular bone and cortical thickening in a “picture-frame” appearance, which is diagnostic of Paget disease of bone (PDB).

questions.text: A previously healthy 59-year-old man comes to the physician with a 6-month history of worsening headaches, difficulty chewing, and progressive hearing loss. Examination shows a mildly tender, 1-cm, hard swelling over the left maxilla. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show a calcium concentration of 8.5 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase activity of 112 U/L, and parathyroid hormone concentration of 30 pg/mL. Audiometry shows bilateral mixed conductive and sensorineural hearing loss. Which of the following processes is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Defective synthesis of type I collagen
Decreased activity of carbonic anhydrase II

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Paget disease of the bone is caused by RANKL-RANK receptor activation, which triggers downstream NF-κB signaling and increases osteoclast activity. To compensate for increased osteoclastic activity, osteoblast activity is also increased. The net result is increased bone turnover with the formation of disorganized (woven) bone, which can cause pathological fractures and/or deformities. Involvement of the cranium can cause headaches, skull enlargement, difficulty chewing (due to dental malocclusion), and mixed hearing loss (due to abnormal ossicles and compression of inner ear structures). Excessive bone turnover also causes an elevation of ALP, as seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased expression of menin protein (a tumor suppressor) is characteristic of MEN 1 syndrome. Patients with MEN1 can develop features of hyperparathyroidism (e.g., increased ALP, bone deformities and brown tumor in severe disease) due to a parathyroid adenoma as well as features of acromegaly (e.g., hearing loss, headache) due to a GH-secreting pituitary adenoma. However, this patient does not have other features characteristic of acromegaly (e.g., coarse facial features, enlarged hands and feet). Also, his normal calcium and PTH levels rule out hyperparathyroidism.

C) INCORRECT:

Defects in the synthesis of dynein are the underlying cause of primary ciliary dyskinesia. Although patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia can present with hearing loss, this condition is associated with poor mucociliary clearance that manifests with recurrent sinusitis, bronchiecstasis, and otitis media, none which are present in this patient. Bone involvement or changes in serum ALP levels would not be expected with primary ciliary dyskinesia.

D) INCORRECT:

Defective synthesis of type 1 collagen is the underlying pathophysiology of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), which can cause bony deformities and mixed hearing loss (due to abnormal ossicles and compression of inner ear structures). However, OI would usually present during childhood with features such as pathological fractures, growth retardation, and blue sclera. Furthermore, patients with osteogenesis imperfecta have decreased bone turnover and would therefore have low, rather than high, ALP levels.
Image Description:

Left: X-ray whole body (AP view); right: X-ray right arm (AP view) of a 3-year-old boy

Osteoporosis is accompanied by severe deformities of the appendicular (examples indicated by green overlay) and axial skeleton (examples indicated by red overlay on left image). Multiple old fractures (red arrows) are associated with callus formation and sclerosis. There is severe limb bowing and foreshortening.

The findings are consistent with osteogenesis imperfecta.

H: humerus; R: radius; U: ulna

E) INCORRECT:

Carbonic anhydrase II is critical for osteoclastic bone resorption. Decreased activity of this enzyme, which is responsible for some forms of osteopetrosis, leads to excessive bone formation without proper bone remodeling. Osteopetrosis can present with elevated ALP levels as well as mixed hearing loss (due to abnormal ossicles and compression of inner ear structures). However, patients with osteopetrosis typically present with diffuse thickening of all bones and pancytopenia (bone marrow failure due to decreased marrow space) beginning in childhood or early adulthood.
Image Description:

X-ray of the thoracic and lumbar spine (AP and lateral view)

Broad, linear sclerotic lesions of the inferior and superior endplates (box 1, highlighted with green overlay in box 3). Normal findings are shown in boxes 2 and 4. This finding is sometimes referred to as “sandwich vertebral body.”

Diagnosis: autosomal-dominant osteopetrosis
questions.hint: Skeletal changes (bony lesions), elevated alkaline phosphatase, and hearing loss with normal serum calcium and parathyroid hormone levels are characteristic of Paget disease of the bone.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of headaches and back pain. Examination shows mild sensorineural hearing loss. Serum concentration of alkaline phosphatase is increased. An x-ray of the skull is shown. The most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient is a drug that has which of the following mechanisms of action?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of tubulin polymerization occurs after administration of vinca alkaloids or colchicine. Vinca drugs are potent antineoplastic agents and colchicine is used in gout. Neither are indicated in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of nuclear factor-κB is the mechanism of denosumab and glucocorticoids. Denosumab is most often used in the treatment of osteoporosis, whereas glucocorticoids can be used as an intraarticular injection to treat osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis and vertebral compression fractures due to osteoporosis can cause back pain but this patient's imaging findings, increased ALP, and new onset hearing loss are consistent with neither osteoporosis nor osteoarthritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Formation of DNA strand breaks is the mechanism by which various antineoplastic drugs, such as bleomycin, cladribine, and doxorubicin, function. Chemotherapy does not have a role in treating Paget disease of bone.

D) INCORRECT:

Stimulation of osteoblasts is the goal of therapy with teriparatide in patients with osteoporosis. This drug is a parathyroid hormone (PTH) analog but has an apparently paradoxical effect when given in a pulsatile fashion compared to the continuous release of PTH under physiologic conditions. Advanced osteoporosis can cause back pain due to compression fractures but osteoporosis would not cause headaches, sensorineural hearing loss, increased ALP, or the imaging findings seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of proteasomes is the mechanism of bortezomib, which is most commonly used in treating multiple myeloma. The patient described here presents with chronic back pain, headache, and osteolytic lesions, all of which could be consistent with multiple myeloma. However, this patient's skull imaging with diffuse sclerosis and calavarial thickening is not consistent with this diagnosis.

F) CORRECT:

The mainstay of treatment for Paget disease of bone is bisphosphonate therapy, which functions by inducing apoptosis of osteoclasts. These drugs bind directly to the bone surface and are eventually taken up by osteoclasts during bone resorption. Once within a cell, they interfere with osteoclast survival, leading to apoptosis and reduced bone resorption.
questions.hint: The combination of hearing loss, headaches, and an elevated alkaline phosphatase concentration is concerning for a diagnosis of Paget disease of bone. The x-ray showing characteristic deformities of bone including thickening of the calvaria, sclerotic and osteolytic lesions, and osteoblastic lesions confirms the diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increased difficulty hearing. She has also had dull and progressive pain in her hip and lower back for the past 2 months that is worse with exertion. Examination of the ears shows impaired hearing on the left with whispered voice test and lateralization to the right with Weber testing. There is localized tenderness over the right hip and groin area with decreased range of motion of the hip. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:


Total protein
6.5 g/dL


Alkaline phosphatase
950 U/L


Calcium
9 mg/dL


Phosphorus
4 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Proliferation of plasma cells in the bone marrow
Decreased bone mass with microarchitectural disruption

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abnormal proliferation of plasma cells in the bone marrow is seen in patients with multiple myeloma (MM), which commonly presents with bone pain and radiographic findings of osteolytic lesions, osteopenia, and/or pathologic fractures. Classic laboratory findings include elevated total protein, anemia, elevated creatinine, and hypercalcemia. While this patient does have bone pain, she does not have any of the other features of MM.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased bone mass and microarchitectural disruption are characteristic of osteoporosis, which is classically diagnosed either on routine screening or after a pathologic fracture has occurred. Commonly affected sites include the lumbar spine, femoral head, distal radius, and humerus. Although age and gender are risk factors for this patient, laboratory findings are usually within the normal range, unlike those of this patient, who has elevated alkaline phosphatase.

C) INCORRECT:

Defective bone matrix mineralization is seen in patients with osteomalacia, a bone disorder that is most commonly due to vitamin D deficiency but may also arise secondary to proximal renal tubular acidosis, hypophosphatemia, or low dietary calcium intake. The presentation and associated laboratory findings of patients with osteomalacia depend largely on the underlying etiology, but generally, osteomalacia manifests as diffuse bone pain, muscle weakness, and/or pathologic fractures. Imaging is non-specific and often reveals low bone mineral density and cortical thinning. This patient's isolated elevation of alkaline phosphatase is not consistent with this diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has Paget disease of bone (PDB), a relatively common, benign condition that is likely hereditary and characterized by accelerated bone turnover, which results in a disorganized bone matrix with abnormal woven bone interspersed with lamellar bone. While most patients are asymptomatic, PDB may manifest with hearing impairment (due to auditory canal narrowing) and bone pain, as seen here. This patient's isolated elevation of alkaline phosphatase is consistent with the diagnosis; calcium, phosphorus, and PTH levels are usually normal in patients with PDB. While osteolytic bone lesions may be seen earlier in the course of the disease, later it is dominated by sclerotic bone with cortical thickening (due to osteoblast activity), and microfissures and fractures are also common. Patients with PDB are at increased risk of high-output heart failure (due to increased blood flow from arteriovenous shunts formed during bone remodeling) and osteogenic sarcoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Cancers that commonly metastasize to bone include prostate cancer, breast cancer, RCC, thyroid cancer, and lung cancer. This patient's age is a risk factor for cancer but the location of her symptoms (e.g., cranial nerve involvement) and isolated elevation in alkaline phosphatase make a different diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: This patient has bone pain, signs of sensorineural hearing loss (lateralization of the Weber test), and an elevated alkaline phosphatase. This combination of findings is suggestive of Paget disease of the bone.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe back pain that began when he was lifting a box 1 hour ago. He also has a 2-year history of increasingly severe right hip pain. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation of the lower spine as well as erythema of the skin over the right hip. Neurologic examination shows decreased hearing in the left ear; the Weber test localizes to the left side. Serum studies show an alkaline phosphatase concentration of 410 U/L, calcium concentration of 9.5 mg/dL, and parathyroid hormone level of 32 pg/mL. An x-ray of the spine shows a fracture of the L4 vertebra. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteitis fibrosa cystica is a manifestation of unopposed osteoclast activation in patients with severe hyperparathyroidism. Affected patients may present with bone pain and elevated serum alkaline phosphatase concentrations, which are seen here. However, serum calcium, parathyroid hormone (PTH), and phosphate concentrations are usually abnormal in osteitis fibrosa cystica. Furthermore, osteitis fibrosa cystica would not explain the hearing loss or the erythema over the area of bone pain seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Osteoporosis is characterized by a decrease in bone mineral density and can manifest with pathological fractures. However, this condition is more common in women and does not cause hearing loss, long-standing bone pain, erythema, or elevated serum alkaline phosphatase concentrations.

C) INCORRECT:

Osteomalacia is characterized by impaired mineralization of the bone (secondary to vitamin D deficiency) and can manifest with bone pain, pathological fractures, and elevated serum alkaline phosphate concentrations. However, this condition does not typically cause hearing loss or erythema over areas of bone pain. In addition, patients with osteomalacia would have decreased serum calcium and phosphate concentrations.

D) CORRECT:

Osteitis deformans is another name for Paget disease of bone, an idiopathic disease associated with increased bone remodeling. The bone remodeling is caused by increased activity of osteoblasts and osteoclasts, which leads to the formation of disorganized (woven) bone that is weaker than normal bone and abnormal in structure. Paget disease of bone therefore manifests with pathological fractures, bone pain with overlying erythema (due to increased vascularity of the underlying bone), and hearing loss (due to ankylosis of the ossicles or compression of the vestibulocochlear nerve). Elevated serum alkaline phosphatase concentrations with normal serum calcium and phosphate concentrations, as seen in this patient, are a hallmark laboratory finding.

E) INCORRECT:

Osteonecrosis results from the interruption of blood supply to a bone, most commonly associated with excessive alcohol consumption or corticosteroid therapy. The long-standing hip pain in this patient could be explained by femoral head osteonecrosis, but not the overlying erythema. Moreover, this condition would not explain this patient's hearing loss or the acute onset of back pain while attempting to lift a box. Furthermore, osteonecrosis does not typically cause elevated serum alkaline phosphatase concentrations, which are seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Osteopetrosis is characterized by increased bone mineralization and can manifest with bone pain, pathological fractures, and hearing loss (due to sclerosis in the skull). However, this condition is a genetically-inherited bone disease and typically manifests at a much earlier age. Furthermore, long-standing osteopetrosis would be characterized by pancytopenia (due to bone marrow replacement) and hepatosplenomegaly (due to extramedullary hematopoiesis), neither of which are seen in this case. Moreover, this condition does not typically cause erythema over areas of bone pain.

Although an elevated alkaline phosphatase value is not typically associated with osteopetrosis, it could be observed in the specific situation where a patient with osteopetrosis has just had a pathological fracture.
questions.hint: This patient has a pathologic fracture of the spine, chronic hip pain, impaired hearing, and an elevated serum alkaline phosphatase concentration (with normal serum calcium and parathyroid hormone).

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man with no significant medical history reports constant, deep, aching pain in the left hip and thigh during the past 4 months. The pain worsens with weight-bearing activities. Acetaminophen and ibuprofen have provided only minimal relief.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Calcium (mg/dL)
9.4
9.0–10.5


25-hydroxyvitamin D (ng/mL)
36
30–80


Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
184
30–120


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.6
0.8–1.3


Radiographs of the left hip show preserved joint space without significant degenerative changes, and no fracture. Thickening of the cortex, coarsening of the trabeculae, and lytic lesions are noted in the femur and pelvis, and a follow-up radionuclide bone scan shows an area of increased uptake over the left hemipelvis.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although naproxen and prednisone might reduce pain, they have no effect on the disease process and are not indicated for treating symptomatic Paget disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Calcitonin does not effectively change the disease process in Paget disease.

C) CORRECT:

An elevated serum level of alkaline phosphatase; radiographic evidence of cortical thickening, coarsening of the trabeculae, and lytic lesions; and increased uptake on bone scintigraphy are key findings of Paget disease of bone. Although the diagnosis can usually be made on the basis of plain radiography and an elevated alkaline phosphate level, a bone scan is indicated at diagnosis to determine the extent of disease. Treatment should be initiated for symptomatic patients who have an elevated serum alkaline phosphatase level.

The symptoms of Paget disease that indicate treatment include the presence of bone pain, fracture, osteolytic lesions, bony deformities, involvement of weight-bearing bones, compression of spinal cord and nerve roots, bone compression of the eighth cranial or optic nerve, and radiculopathy. Treatment is also indicated when surgical intervention on an affected bone is anticipated.

High-potency, long-acting, intravenous bisphosphonates, such as zoledronic acid, are effective for lowering the alkaline phosphatase level and improving quality of life in patients with Paget disease. Although etidronate, a non-nitrogen-containing bisphosphonate, is approved for the treatment of Paget disease of bone, it is much less effective than nitrogen-containing bisphosphonates, such as zoledronic acid, and is therefore not the best choice for first-line treatment. It is generally reserved for second-line treatment in patients who are intolerant of nitrogen-containing bisphosphonates. In addition, etidronate can cause impaired bone mineralization, which can lead to increased fracture risk; it is therefore contraindicated in patients who have lytic lesions in weight-bearing bones.

Key learning point: The first-line therapy for symptomatic Paget disease of bone is a high-potency intravenous bisphosphonate.

D) INCORRECT:

Although etidronate, a non-nitrogen-containing bisphosphonate, is approved for the treatment of Paget disease of bone, it is much less effective than nitrogen-containing bisphosphonates, such as zoledronic acid, and is therefore not the best choice for first-line treatment. It is generally reserved for second-line treatment in patients who are intolerant of nitrogen-containing bisphosphonates. In addition, etidronate can cause impaired bone mineralization, which can lead to increased fracture risk; it is therefore contraindicated in patients who have lytic lesions in weight-bearing bones.

E) INCORRECT:

Although naproxen and prednisone might reduce pain, they have no effect on the disease process and are not indicated for treating symptomatic Paget disease.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old previously healthy woman is noted to have an alkaline phosphatase level of 217 U/liter (reference range, 30–120). Notable results on repeat laboratory testing are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
239
30–120


Calcium (mg/dL)
9.3
9.0–10.5


Phosphorus (mg/dL)
3.6
3.0–4.5


Albumin (g/dL)
3.6
3.5–5.5


γ- Glutamyltransferase (U/liter)
34
1–94


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
0.8
0.3–1.0


25-hydroxyvitamin D (ng/mL)
33
30–80


Other blood tests - including other electrolyte levels, kidney function, liver function, and complete blood count — are normal. The patient reports no symptoms. Physical examination is unremarkable.
What is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient?

choices.text: Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry of the spine and hip
Ultrasonography of the right upper quadrant

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry does not help in evaluating an elevated alkaline phosphatase level; it is used to diagnose osteoporosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Ultrasonography of the right upper quadrant would be reasonable only if the alkaline phosphatase elevation was not in isolation and rather was accompanied by elevations in gamma-glutamyltransferase or bilirubin; isolated elevations of alkaline phosphatase are almost certainly elevations in bone-specific alkaline phosphatase.

C) INCORRECT:

Although plain films in a skeletal survey of affected areas can be useful, bone scintigraphy is the best first step in evaluating an asymptomatic person with suspected Paget disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Although plain films in CT scans of affected areas can be useful, bone scintigraphy is the best first step in evaluating an asymptomatic person with suspected Paget disease.

E) CORRECT:

When the alkaline phosphatase level is elevated but the gamma-glutamyltransferase level is normal, the alkaline phosphatase elevation is likely to be of bone (not hepatobiliary) origin. In an asymptomatic older adult with alkaline phosphatase elevation of bone origin, the most likely diagnosis is Paget disease, a disorder of bone resorption and repair.

Paget disease is frequently asymptomatic and diagnosed only because of an incidental elevation in the alkaline phosphatase level or an incidental finding on imaging. Whether symptomatic or not, all patients with an elevated alkaline phosphatase level should undergo bone scintigraphy to assess the extent of disease. Plain films of hot spots will confirm whether they are areas of Paget disease. If areas of concern are involved (such as weight-bearing long bones or areas near joints or neurovascular structures) or if any of the involved areas is symptomatic, then treatment should be initiated.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test to evaluate an asymptomatic, isolated elevation of the alkaline phosphatase level when the gamma-glutamyltransferase level is normal is bone scintigraphy to help diagnose Paget disease.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents with a persistent ache in her right leg that has been increasing for the past 2 weeks and is exacerbated by weight-bearing. She does not recall any fall or injury. Pain relief with the use of acetaminophen and ibuprofen is incomplete.
Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.8
0.6–1.1


Calcium (mg/dL)
9.8
9.0–10.5


Albumin (g/dL)
3.8
3.5–5.5


Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
22
0–35


Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
18
0–35


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
0.6
0.3–1.0



Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
265
30–120


Bone-specific alkaline phosphatase (μg/liter)
56.0
7.0–22.4


25-hydroxyvitamin D (ng/mL)
32
30–80


Plain radiography of the right tibia and fibula is performed (figure).
Bone scintigraphy shows enhanced uptake limited to the distal right lower leg. MRI confirms cortical thickening of the tibia but no underlying mass.
Which one of the following treatments is the most appropriate next step in this patient's care?

choices.text: Biopsy of the area of cortical thickening

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cinacalcet is not indicated for treating patients with Paget disease. Cinacalcet is a calcimimetic agent approved for treating secondary hyperparathyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

The drug teriparatide is a parathyroid-hormone agonist that is approved for treating osteoporosis but is specifically contraindicated for use in Paget disease.

C) CORRECT:

Paget disease evolves from an early lytic or hot phase, through an intermediate phase, to a cold phase marked by dense bone formation. Plain radiography shows both osteolytic and sclerotic lesions in the same bone, as well as cortical thickening and an increase in bone dimension that can be a marker of more advanced disease. This patient's pain, elevated alkaline phosphatase level, and imaging findings are most consistent with a diagnosis of monostotic Paget disease. However, many patients with Paget disease are asymptomatic.

Indications for treating Paget disease include bone pain, headaches from skull involvement, neurologic symptoms, and fissure fractures. Because bisphosphonates inhibit osteoclastic bone resorption, they are beneficial in treating the increased bone remodeling seen in Paget disease. Although alendronate, etidronate, pamidronate, risedronate, and zoledronic acid can each be used, zoledronic acid has become the first-line treatment because of the convenience of controlling the disease with only a single intravenous dose of medication. Salmon calcitonin has also been approved for active disease.

Key learning point: The best treatment for active Paget disease is a bisphosphonate.

D) INCORRECT:

A biopsy may be prudent if a mass were suggested on imaging or the patient had a history of cancer. Bone biopsy is not routinely indicated for patients with features of Paget disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Calcitriol is not indicated for treating patients with Paget disease. Calcitriol provides activated vitamin D for treatment of hypoparathyroidism.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man comes to the office because of a 2-month history of severe right hip pain. The pain is worse at night. He has chronic headaches and back pain for which he takes vitamin D, calcium supplements, and ibuprofen. Examination shows hip tenderness and mild sensorineural hearing loss. Laboratory studies show an increased alkaline phosphatase level. X-ray of the hip shows a radiolucent lesion in the ilium with a moth-eaten appearance, wide transition zone, and an aggressive periosteal reaction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Multiple myeloma commonly affects the axial skeleton (including the pelvis), has a peak incidence at 50–70 years, and would cause radiolucent lesions on x-ray. This patient's history of chronic back pain, chronic headaches (skull involvement), and hearing loss (SNHL) are also consistent with the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. However, multiple myeloma would appear as well-defined (narrow transition zone) lesions on x-ray with a punched-out appearance and minimal periosteal reaction.

B) INCORRECT:

Chondrosarcoma is associated with PDB, often affects the pelvis, can appear as an ill-defined (wide transition zone), radiolucent lesion with a moth-eaten appearance and aggressive periosteal reaction as seen here. However, an x-ray of a chondrosarcoma would typically reveal ring-and-arc or popcorn-like calcification within the tumor. These features are not seen in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Osteosarcoma is the most common bone malignancy associated with PDB. Destruction of normal bone results in an osteolytic (radiolucent) lesion with an ill-defined border (wide transition zone) and a moth-eaten appearance. Aggressive periosteal reactions (e.g., sunburst appearance, Codman triangle) indicate lifting of the periosteum following rapid tumor growth. Other risk factors for developing osteosarcomas are bone infarcts, radiation, retinoblastoma gene mutations, and Li-Fraumeni syndrome.

Secondary osteosarcomas, which develop in diseased bone, typically manifest in older individuals. In contrast, primary osteosarcomas, which develop in previously normal bone, have a peak incidence at 10–20 years of age, with metaphyses of long bones (typically the distal femur, proximal tibia) more commonly affected than flat bones (e.g., the ilium).

D) INCORRECT:

Ewing sarcoma can occur in flat bones such as the ilium and appear as an ill-defined (wide transition zone), radiolucent lesion with a moth-eaten appearance and an aggressive periosteal reaction (e.g., a lamellated “onion-skin” reaction). However, Ewing sarcoma is not a complication of PDB, which this patient has.

E) INCORRECT:

A giant cell tumor of the bone (osteoclastoma), which is a rare complication of PDB. However, osteoclastomas typically affect the epiphyseal regions of long bones, rather than flat bones like the ilium, and an x-ray would show a well-defined (narrow transition zone) lesion with a non-aggressive periosteal reaction and a soap-bubble appearance.
questions.hint: This patient likely has Paget disease of the bone (PDB), which, when symptomatic, manifests with nonspecific features such as bone pain. The sensorineural hearing loss is likely due to bony compression of the vestibulocochlear nerve. Chronically increased bone turnover in patients with long-standing PDB increases the risk of a certain bone malignancy.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents with a persistent ache in her right leg that has been increasing for the past 2 weeks and is exacerbated by weight-bearing. She does not recall any fall or injury. Pain relief with the use of acetaminophen and ibuprofen is incomplete. Physical examination is unremarkable. Serum findings include the following levels:


Creatinine
0.8 mg/dL


Calcium
9.8 mg/dL


Albumin
3.8 g/dL


Alkaline phosphatase
265 U/L


25-hydroxyvitamin D
32 ng/mL (N = 30–80)


X-ray of the right tibia and fibula is shown. Bone scintigraphy shows enhanced uptake limited to the distal right lower leg. MRI confirms cortical thickening of the tibia but no underlying mass. Which of the following treatments is the most appropriate next step in this patient's care?

choices.text: Biopsy of the area of cortical thickening

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cinacalcet is not indicated for treating patients with Paget disease. Cinacalcet is a calcimimetic agent approved for treating secondary hyperparathyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

The drug teriparatide is a parathyroid-hormone agonist that is approved for treating osteoporosis but is specifically contraindicated for use in Paget disease.

C) CORRECT:

Paget disease evolves from an early lytic or hot phase, through an intermediate phase, to a cold phase marked by dense bone formation. Indications for treating Paget disease include bone pain, headaches from skull involvement, neurologic symptoms, and fissure fractures. Because bisphosphonates inhibit osteoclastic bone resorption, they are beneficial in treating the increased bone remodeling seen in Paget disease. Although alendronate, etidronate, pamidronate, risedronate, and zoledronic acid can each be used, zoledronic acid has become the first-line treatment because of the convenience of controlling the disease with only a single intravenous dose of medication. Salmon calcitonin has also been approved for active disease.

Key learning point: The best treatment for active Paget disease is a bisphosphonate.

D) INCORRECT:

A biopsy may be prudent if a mass were suggested on imaging or the patient had a history of cancer. Bone biopsy is not routinely indicated for patients with features of Paget disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Calcitriol is not indicated for treating patients with Paget disease. Calcitriol provides activated vitamin D for treatment of hypoparathyroidism.
questions.hint: This patient's pain, elevated alkaline phosphatase level, and imaging findings (osteolytic and sclerotic lesions in the same bone, cortical thickening and an increase in bone dimension) are most consistent with a diagnosis of monostotic Paget disease.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of severe right hip pain that is worse at night. He has a history of chronic headaches and back pain, for which he takes vitamin D, calcium supplements, and ibuprofen. On examination, there is hip tenderness and mild sensorineural hearing loss. Laboratory studies reveal an increased alkaline phosphatase level. X-ray of the hip shows a radiolucent lesion in the ilium with a moth-eaten appearance, wide transition zone, and an aggressive periosteal reaction. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Multiple myeloma commonly affects the axial skeleton (including the pelvis), has a peak incidence at 50–70 years, and would cause radiolucent lesions on x-ray. This patient's history of chronic back pain, chronic headaches (skull involvement), and hearing loss (SNHL) are also consistent with the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. However, multiple myeloma would appear as well-defined (narrow transition zone) lesions on x-ray with a punched-out appearance and minimal periosteal reaction.

B) CORRECT:

Osteosarcoma is the most common bone malignancy associated with PDB. Destruction of normal bone results in an osteolytic (radiolucent) lesion with an ill-defined border (wide transition zone) and a moth-eaten appearance. Aggressive periosteal reactions (e.g., sunburst appearance, Codman triangle) indicate lifting of the periosteum following rapid tumor growth. Other risk factors for developing osteosarcomas are bone infarcts, radiation, retinoblastoma gene mutations, and Li-Fraumeni syndrome.

Secondary osteosarcomas, which develop in diseased bone, typically manifest in older individuals. In contrast, primary osteosarcomas, which develop in previously normal bone, have a peak incidence at 10–20 years of age, with metaphyses of long bones (typically the distal femur, proximal tibia) more commonly affected than flat bones (e.g., the ilium).

Key learning point: Osteosarcoma is the most common bone malignancy arising in Paget disease of bone, typically presenting as an aggressive, ill-defined, radiolucent lesion with a moth-eaten appearance and periosteal reaction on imaging.

C) INCORRECT:

Ewing sarcoma can occur in flat bones such as the ilium and appear as an ill-defined (wide transition zone), radiolucent lesion with a moth-eaten appearance and an aggressive periosteal reaction (e.g., a lamellated “onion-skin” reaction). However, Ewing sarcoma is not a complication of PDB, which this patient has.

D) INCORRECT:

A giant cell tumor of the bone (osteoclastoma), which is a rare complication of PDB. However, osteoclastomas typically affect the epiphyseal regions of long bones, rather than flat bones like the ilium, and an x-ray would show a well-defined (narrow transition zone) lesion with a non-aggressive periosteal reaction and a soap-bubble appearance.

E) INCORRECT:

Chondrosarcoma is associated with PDB, often affects the pelvis, can appear as an ill-defined (wide transition zone), radiolucent lesion with a moth-eaten appearance and aggressive periosteal reaction as seen here. However, an x-ray of a chondrosarcoma would typically reveal ring-and-arc or popcorn-like calcification within the tumor. These features are not seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient likely has Paget disease of the bone (PDB), which, when symptomatic, manifests with nonspecific features such as bone pain. The sensorineural hearing loss is likely due to bony compression of the vestibulocochlear nerve. Chronically increased bone turnover in patients with long-standing PDB increases the risk of a certain bone malignancy.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a persistent ache in her right leg that has been worsening over the past 2 weeks and is aggravated by weight-bearing. She does not recall any fall or injury. Acetaminophen and ibuprofen provide only partial relief. Physical examination is unremarkable. Serum studies show the following:


Creatinine, blood
71 μmol/L (49–93)


Calcium (Ca), total, blood
2.45 mmol/L (2.12–2.52)


Albumin, blood
38 g/L (34–50)


Alkaline phosphatase, blood

265 IU/L (50–136)


Vitamin D (25-hydroxyvitamin D), blood
80 nmol/L (75–250)


An X-ray of the right tibia and fibula is provided. Bone scintigraphy shows increased uptake limited to the distal right lower leg. MRI demonstrates cortical thickening of the tibia without evidence of an underlying mass. Which one of the following treatments is the most appropriate next step in her care?

choices.text: Biopsy of the area of cortical thickening.

Salmon calcitonin has also been approved for active disease.
